L’évolution de la population mondiale (9 à 10 milliards en 2050) et son enrichissement progressif devraient se traduire par une augmentation considérable de la consommation en énergie à l’échelle de la planète. Ceci sera d’autant plus vrai que le mode de vie des pays industrialisés, extrêmement énergivore en ressources fossiles, semble servir de modèle de développement à l’ensemble du globe.

L’accès à l’énergie est un facteur majeur de développement et d’émancipation des populations. En effet, l’accès à l’énergie facilite l’accès à l’éducation, réduit les inégalités hommes/femmes, améliore très fortement la santé et contribue ainsi à réduire la pauvreté. En sécurisant la situation des familles, l’accès à l ‘énergie s’accompagne plus ou moins rapidement d’une baisse de la natalité et ainsi d’une réduction de la pression démographique.

Un enjeu majeur demeure de combler les énormes inégalités existantes quant à l’accès à l’énergie, que ce soit à l’échelle du globe qu’au sein même des pays.

L’eau potable est un bien commun, un droit qui doit profiter à tous. Aujourd’hui, c’est la Banque Mondiale qui finance la majeure partie de l’approvisionnement en eau, alors que les multinationales privées (Bechtel, Suez, Vivendi, Lyonnaise des eaux, RWE/Thames Water et Saur) gèrent environ 5 % des ressources mondiales en eau.

Selon le Conseil mondial de l'eau, d'énormes investissements seront nécessaires dans les pays en développement pour moderniser l’existant et créer de nouveaux équipements (usines de production, réseaux de distribution, stations d’assainissement), mais aussi pour développer de nouveaux systèmes d'irrigation. Ces investissements ont été évalués par le Conseil mondial de l'eau à 180 milliards de dollars par an pour les 25 prochaines années, contre 75 milliards de dollars actuellement investis chaque année.

Qui doit financer ces investissements ? Faut-il privatiser la gestion de l’eau ? Qui doit fixer le prix de l’eau ? Le Conseil de l'eau recommande fortement de faire appel aux investisseurs privés, tandis les ONG critiquent cette approche, où l'État jouerait un rôle de «simple régulateur». Leur argument majeur est qu'une telle privatisation se ferait toujours au détriment des populations les plus pauvres et sans pour autant garantir une plus grande efficacité.

La finance sert le développement… et ce développement génère des émissions de carbone. Mais la finance mondiale a un rôle central à jouer dans la lutte contre le réchauffement climatique, par l'intermédiaire de ce qu'on appelle la finance carbone. Son objectif est de réduire les émissions de gaz à effet de serre dans l'atmosphère, en favorisant des investissements financiers dans des techniques moins polluantes.

La finance est donc un des outils à notre portée pour orienter les financements vers des initiatives plus vertueuses en matière d’émissions et peut contribuer au renforcement de la résistance aux effets du changement climatique. La taxe carbone est un des outils envisagés pour orienter l’économie et les comportements humains vers des solutions plus propres.

Le levier financier a été et demeure encore un moyen extrêmement puissant de soutien du développement des économies carbonées. Les subventions directes et indirectes à l'exploitation des énergies fossiles, mais également à l’industrie nucléaire, a conduit à cette illusion d’une énergie peu chère et presque infinie, retardant d’autant la prise de conscience de son vrai prix. Le prix de sa limitation dans le temps, car les réserves dans nos sous-sols sont limitées, et également le prix des externalités négatives qui ne sont pas intégrées dans le prix affiché mais que la collectivité paie bien d’une manière ou d’une autre (pollutions, santé publique, guerres pour les réserves…). En termes d’investissement et d’aide au développement nord/sud, les politiques des banques commencent - très marginalement - à s’interroger sur l’intérêt de continuer de soutenir des énergies fossiles ou au contraire de favoriser le développement des énergies renouvelables.

Nous commençons collectivement à prendre conscience que le coût de l’inaction face aux bouleversements climatiques et à nos modèles énergétiques sera au final immensément plus lourd à supporter que celui d’un investissement dans la transition énergétique.

L’eau et le climat sont intimement liés. Avec le réchauffement climatique, les inondations et les épisodes de sécheresse seront plus fréquents et plus prononcés, avec des conséquences sur le régime des fleuves et des ressources en eau. De plus, la montée du niveau des mers, au-delà de ses effets sur les littoraux, risque de provoquer l’intrusion d’eau salée dans les nappes contenant de l’eau douce. Environ 1% d'eau de mer suffit pour altérer la qualité de l'eau souterraine. Plus de 2 milliards de personnes dans le monde dépendent des nappes phréatiques pour leur accès à l'eau potable.

Le réchauffement climatique fait aussi fondre certains glaciers, dont de nombreuses populations sont dépendantes pour leur accès à l’eau. Maîtriser le changement climatique représente donc un défi d’autant plus essentiel qu’il va se combiner à l’accroissement de la population mondiale et à la concentration de l’humanité dans de grands centres urbains, qui sont de grands consommateurs d’eau. En 2050, environ 75% de la population mondiale vivrait en ville.

L’eau a toujours été une source d’énergie mécanique. Une des premières formes d’énergie était le courant des rivières qui permettait de faire tourner la meule du meunier, les pistons et turbines. Ce type de production d’énergie présente l’avantage de ne pas consommer d’énergie, mais l’inconvénient de dégager un faible rendement.

De nombreuses infrastructures dédiées à la production d’énergie à partir de l’eau nécessitent la construction de barrages qui posent d’autres problèmes humains, sociaux et contribuent à la perte de biodiversités. Par ailleurs, l’exploitation des énergies fossiles provoque des pollutions et contaminations importantes de réserves d’eau utilisées pour l’agriculture ou l’alimentation. C’est encore plus dramatique en ce qui concerne l’exploitation des ressources non conventionnelles (gaz de schiste et sables bitumineux).

D’un autre côté, la puissance énergétique propose une réponse possible aux régions en manque chronique d’eau douce avec la désalinisation de l’eau de mer. Mais là encore, c’est un processus très énergivore, l’enjeu reposant dans le type d’énergie qui permet cet approvisionnement d’eau douce.

C'est en 1967 que les premières prévisions d’un réchauffement planétaire ont lieu. Deux scientifiques prévoient le doublement de la concentration de CO2 d’ici le début du XXIème siècle et une élévation de la température moyenne de 2,5 degrés. A peu près 20 ans plus tard, en 1988, le GIEC est créé. Le climat, au centre des préoccupations environnementales aujourd'hui, joue un rôle central dans la diffusion de l'idée de développement durable.

Mais cette notion de « développement » durable est-elle compatible avec la lutte contre le réchauffement climatique ?

La demande croissante en énergie est étroitement liée avec la hausse du PIB, et donc le développement. Le développement engendre une une consommation croissante d’énergie responsable des bouleversements climatiques. Ainsi, la notion de décroissance ne serait-elle pas plus adaptée que la notion de « développement durable » si on considère qu’un des plus gros enjeux à venir est la question du climat, et donc de la baisse de la demande en énergies non renouvelables ?

Comment adapter nos modèles démocratiques aux grands enjeux environnementaux qui ne connaissent pas de frontières ? Une démocratie planétaire est-elle réaliste ?

Le défi climatique ne connaît pas de frontières. Alors que 10 pays au monde sont responsables de 70% des émissions de gaz à effet de serre, les effets du réchauffement sont inégaux. Une gouvernance mondiale est nécessaire et des décisions doivent être prises rapidement et efficacement. En ce sens, la lutte contre le changement climatique est-elle compatible avec la démocratie ? Une prise de conscience planétaire est-elle possible ? Dans un monde bien que globalisé, riche de cultures et de coutumes, peut-on tous adopter un mode de vie plus respectueux de l’environnement ? Quelle est la place de la liberté individuelle ? Faut-il une dictature « éclairée » pour résoudre la question climatique ?

Des vagues de chaleur plus fréquentes et plus intenses, des modifications des milieux de vie, des migrations de population et d’animaux font partie des effets attendus du réchauffement climatique.

Ces changements vont avoir des impacts non négligeables sur la santé humaine. De nouvelles maladies vont voir le jour auxquelles nous ne sommes pas préparés. Par exemple, des maladies tropicales vont se développer dans des zones où le climat est aujourd’hui tempéré. Entre 2030 et 2050, on s’attend à ce que le changement climatique entraîne près de 250 000 décès supplémentaires par an, dus à la malnutrition, au paludisme, à la diarrhée et au stress lié à la chaleur. On estime que le coût des dommages directs pour la santé se situe entre 2 et 4 milliards de dollars US par an d’ici 2030.

Par ailleurs, les zones n’ayant pas de bonnes infrastructures de santé, pour la plupart dans les pays en développement, seront les moins en mesure de se préparer et de faire face à la situation sans assistance. La réduction des émissions de gaz à effet de serre, en élargissant le choix des transports, de l’alimentation et des énergies, peut entraîner une amélioration de la santé.

La croissance démographique aura mécaniquement pour effet de renforcer le dérèglement climatique. Le mode de vie occidental est extrêmement émetteur en GES et semble servir de modèle de développement économique sur l’ensemble du globe.

Néanmoins, la contribution des différents pays au réchauffement climatique n’est pas directement proportionnelle à leur population. La Chine est par exemple le pays le plus peuplé du monde et aussi le premier émetteur de GES, mais son taux d'émission de CO2 par habitant est loin derrière celui des États-Unis, du Canada, de l'Australie, de la Russie et des pays européens.

Par ailleurs, les dérèglements climatiques vont affecter très fortement les conditions de l’agriculture (moins de terres nouvelles à cultiver, aggravation de catastrophes naturelles, plus grande incertitude des récoltes…) et accroitre l’insécurité alimentaire de la grande majorité des 10 milliards d’êtres humains qui peupleront la Terre à 2050.

Le réchauffement climatique sera également la cause d’importants déplacements de population. D’ici 2050, 150 à 200 millions de personnes devraient migrer en raison des conséquences du dérèglement climatique, que ce soit pour cause d’élévation du niveau des mers que pour aggravation de sécheresses, famine... (source : Christian Aid).

La finance sert le développement…et ce développement génère des émissions de carbone. Mais la finance mondiale a un rôle central à jouer dans la lutte contre le réchauffement climatique, par l'intermédiaire de ce qu'on appelle la finance carbone. Son objectif est de réduire les émissions de gaz à effet de serre dans l'atmosphère, en favorisant des investissements financiers dans des techniques moins polluantes.

La finance est donc un des outils à notre portée pour orienter les financements vers des initiatives plus vertueuses en matière d’émissions et peut contribuer au renforcement de la résistance aux effets du changement climatique. La taxe carbone est à cet égard un des outils envisagés pour orienter l’économie et les comportements humains vers des solutions plus propres.

L’eau et le climat sont intimement liés. Avec le réchauffement climatique, les inondations et les épisodes de sécheresse seront plus fréquents et plus prononcés, avec des conséquences sur le régime des fleuves et des ressources en eau. De plus, la montée du niveau des mers va peser sur les littoraux mais risque aussi de provoquer l’intrusion d’eau salée dans les nappes contenant de l’eau douce. Environ 1% d'eau de mer suffit pour altérer la qualité de l'eau souterraine. Plus de 2 milliards de personnes dans le monde dépendent des nappes phréatiques pour leur accès à l'eau potable.

Le réchauffement climatique fait aussi fondre certains glaciers. Or, de nombreuses populations dépendent de ces glaciers pour leur accès à l’eau. Maîtriser le changement climatique représente donc un défi essentiel. D’autant plus qu’il va se combiner à l’accroissement de la population mondiale et à la concentration de l’humanité dans de grands centres urbains, qui sont de grands consommateurs d’eau. En 2050, environ 75% de la population mondiale vivrait en ville.

L’énergie et plus particulièrement les énergies fossiles (pétrole, charbon, gaz) sont au cœur de nos modèles de développement et ont permis les grandes révolutions technologiques. Elles représentent 81% de l’énergie consommée dans le monde et contribue à 60% des émissions de gaz à effet de serre, responsables du bouleversement climatique. Et si l’on peut se réjouir du développement économique mondial à venir, notamment pour les pays du sud, poursuivre sur ce modèle n’est pas compatible avec la lutte contre le réchauffement climatique.

Par ailleurs, nos infrastructures énergétiques actuelles sont très sensibles aux aléas climatiques, que ce soit les centrales thermiques - réactives aux hausses de température -, ou les énergies renouvelables (photovoltaïque et éolien) dont le rendement pourrait être affecté par la multiplication des aléas climatiques.

Des modèles émergent qui prônent une transition rapide mais raisonnée vers les énergies renouvelables et une organisation relocalisée des moyens de production d’énergie.

L’énergie et plus particulièrement les énergies fossiles (pétrole, charbon, gaz) sont au cœur de nos modèles de développement et ont permis les grandes révolutions technologiques. Elles représentent 81% de l’énergie consommée dans le monde et contribuent à 60% des émissions de gaz à effet de serre, responsables du bouleversement climatique. Et si l’on peut se réjouir du développement économique mondial à venir, notamment pour les pays du sud, poursuivre sur ce modèle n’est pas compatible avec la lutte contre réchauffement climatique.

Par ailleurs, nos infrastructures énergétiques actuelles sont très sensibles aux aléas climatiques, que ce soit les centrales thermiques - réactives aux hausses de température -, ou les énergies renouvelables (photovoltaïque et éolien) dont le rendement pourrait être affecté par la multiplication des aléas climatiques. Des modèles émergent qui prônent une transition rapide mais raisonnée vers les énergies renouvelables et une organisation relocalisée des moyens de production d’énergie.

“Le changement climatique est l’un des plus grands défis de notre temps”, Kofi Annan, 7ème secrétaire général des Nations Unies.

Nous partageons tous la même planète, le défi climatique ne connaît pas de frontières ! Pourtant, si certains États sont plus pollueurs que d’autres (10 pays au monde sont responsables de 70% des émissions de gaz à effet de serre), ce sont d’autres régions, parmi les plus pauvres de la planète, qui devraient être le plus impactées par le réchauffement climatique.

L’enjeu d’adopter une coordination globale est de taille. La question climatique ne peut se résoudre à l’échelle locale . Elle oblige à dépasser les intérêts politiques et économiques de chacun pour viser l’intérêt commun mondial de maintenir des conditions de vie humainement supportables sur Terre. Toutes les régions du monde étant concernées, c’est un formidable défi interculturel.

En 1988, le GIEC (Groupe d’experts intergouvernemental sur l’Evolution du Climat)a été créé, afin d’apporter un éclairage scientifique, international et non partisan sur la question. En 1992, lors du Sommet de la Terre à Rio, 192 pays signent la Convention Cadre des Nations Unies sur le Changement Climatique (CCNUCC) et s’engagent ainsi à stabiliser leurs émissions de gaz à effet de serre. On décide de tenir une conférence chaque année, que l’on appellera « Conférence des Parties » (COP) pour accompagner la mise en œuvre pratique de la Convention. Ce sont là les prémices d'une Gouvernance mondiale sur le Climat, que la criticité des enjeux climatiques obligera à intensifier.

Lithium, Radium, Cobalt, Cuivre, Fer…une grande famille de métaux cachés dans tous les objets de notre quotidien et de notre intimité. Ils sont tellement proches de nous que nous n’avons plus conscience de leur présence. Nous ne savons pas non plus comment ils sont produits et nous oublions qu’ils ne sont pas éternels.

L’extraction de ces ressources présentes sur Terre en quantités très limitées ainsi que leur transformation pour nos habitations, infrastructures, transports, ordinateurs, téléphones, peintures… est extrêmement consommatrice d’énergie . Aujourd’hui cette énergie est essentiellement issue de ressources fossiles, principales responsables des émissions de GES et donc des bouleversements climatiques.

Si l’extraction de ces métaux et terres rares contribue au réchauffement du climat, les effets de ce réchauffement concourent aussi à des découvertes précieuses qui intéressent certains pays au plus haut point. C’est le cas du Groenland, où la fonte de la calotte glacière laisse entrevoir des trésors rendus plus accessibles… Après la Chine, ce territoire serait la 2ème réserve mondiale en terres rares et la cinquième réserve en uranium ! Selon les premières prospections, le Groenland pourrait répondre à 25% de la demande mondiale en terres rares.

Sustainable development tackles the social, environmental and economic dimensions of all the issues affecting the development of our societies. While an increasingly significant part of the planet has gradually benefited from economic development, its democratic dimension continues to be brought into question.

Who makes the decisions? Do our elected officials stand for our general interests or are they concerned about preserving common goods? How much corruption is there and how influential are lobbyists? Do our democratic systems ensure a better distribution of equitable wealth than the other political models?

Is “sustainable” development part and parcel of a democratic system? It underpins the consideration of all the stakeholders involved, while its process of reflection covers public consultation and participation.

It offers a particularly large, diverse space for reinvention so we can build different ways of living together.

“Human beings are at the centre of concerns for sustainable development. They are entitled to a healthy and productive life in harmony with nature” (Principle 1 of the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, 1992).

Health is at the centre of the principles behind sustainable development and at the crossroads between environmental, social, societal and governance challenges.

While economic development, which has gradually benefited almost every country since the mid-20th century, coincides with an overall improvement in public health (an unprecedented increase in life expectancy and a decline in many diseases), it also brings with it numerous mechanisms that affect people’s health all over the world. Climate change, air, water and soil pollution, as well as worsening inequalities can all affect the state of health of our fellow citizens and therefore the ability of every individual to think of their own development and build their future.

Conversely, poor health conditions can also be behind economic downturns: it is estimated that malaria causes a downturn in economic growth of up to 1.3% per year in endemic African countries.

Population growth naturally raises the question of sustainable development for future generations. The world’s population is therefore a multiplying factor for all the other parameters involved in development issues. The same energy consumption or food production model will automatically have a very different impact on our environment depending on whether there are 4 billion of us, as in the mid-20th century, or between 9 and 10 billion, as predicted by 2050.

We are already feeling the tangible impacts of population growth and our development model on the environment: the deterioration of air quality, water poisoning and dwindling natural resources. Today, 20 megacities account for 9% of the world’s population, and tomorrow, half of the world’s population will live in cities, which will cause real problems for resource management. Social inequalities are on the rise, while social conflicts are getting worse. People are fighting for water, land and unused resources.

Furthermore, climate change is forcing many migratory flows that often cause serious human problems. According to the Global Estimates annual report by the Norwegian Refugee Council, in 2013 three times more people were forced to leave their homes following a natural disaster than were displaced by conflict.

Are finance and sustainable development two mutually exclusive concepts?

The world of finance is often seen as obscure and dehumanised, only taking into account the economic interests of speculators. Can we incorporate environmental conservation and social equity into financial thinking? How do we strike a balance between economics and ecology in a crisis where there is uneven awareness of climate risks? Can we overcome the difficulties of implementing carbon finance and change the behaviour of economic and financial stakeholders?

Today, an increasing amount of investors are aware of non-financial criteria and look to make profitable yet ethical investments. Socially responsible investment (SRI) takes extra-financial criteria into account to guide investors with their choices. Indeed, the priorities of responsible investment have mobilised new stakeholders, who have formed coalitions, initiatives, declarations, networks and other organisations (Principles for Responsible Investment, Global Compact, UNEP-FI, The Equator Principles, etc.). Other forms of financing have come to light, such as the microfinance launched by Muhammad Yunus, the creator behind the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh.

Do we also have to monetise common goods, putting a price on the services provided by nature in order to protect them? While finance and sustainable development may at first sight seem mutually exclusive terms, new development paths will only open up if our financial models are reinvented.

Water is a resource that we must preserve, a vital common good for humanity.

Under demographic pressure and agricultural intensification, our fresh water reserves are being overexploited and water quality is changing. Today, one third of the world’s population does not have access to water and the plaque of “water stress” no longer just affects developing countries. The city of Detroit also found itself without running water and had to appeal to the UN to demand its “right” to water. An increasing number of conflicts of interest on water management are appearing between the agriculture and food sectors, industries and population groups.

From a sustainable development perspective, there are many types of water-related goals:
- environmental (to limit the pollution of rivers, oceans, seas and groundwater);
- educational (to avoid water wastage and to implement sensible consumption of water);
- social (to make water access and availability democratic for everyone, ensuring health security with water access).


Achieving these goals also requires the implementation of governance organisations and arrangements to provide shared economic management of these vital yet rare resources that are unevenly distributed.

Universal (healthcare) Coverage ensures that the whole population has access to equitable, quality and affordable health services. Universal Coverage has its roots in the WHO Constitution, which was adopted in 1948 and establishes health as one of the basic rights of every human being, and in the Global Strategy for Health for All, which was launched in 1979.

Is this universal coverage possible? The market of life, which aims to push back the prospect of death ever further, is a lucrative business: the economic interests of pharmaceutical industries, patents, research in the fields of transhumanism and immortality, technological progress and medical data held by Internet giants, etc. In response, the UN, the WHO and international aid are fighting to guarantee healthcare access for the poorest people. For hundreds of millions of people and, in particular, for the most vulnerable, universal coverage is their only hope of improving their health without further impoverishment.

Is a democratic, fair healthcare system possible or is it just a utopia?

Athens, the birthplace of democracy, had a population of 250,000. While during the French Revolution, France had the highest population in Europe: it had less than 28 million inhabitants and would be considered a small country by 21st century standards.

Looking at the difficulties of the EU’s enlargement to 26 countries, following reports that the world’s population will continue to grow, reaching 9 or 10 billion people by 2050, we may wonder whether there is an optimum, even maximum, number of inhabitants that should live in the same area in order for democracy to work properly.

Population growth is one of the leading challenges of the next century. In 2015, the old democracies only accounted for 13% of the world’s population of 7 billion people. Will the cultural influence of emerging countries, these strong demographic powers, allow us to develop new democratic models tailored for large populations?

Since 1989, Porto Alegre has paved the way for a new form of democratic finance with its participatory budgeting. This Brazilian city has shown that an alternative distribution of power among citizens and institutions is viable. The initiative has inspired the alter-globalists involved in the fight against neoliberalism, who thought that this democratic idea would help to redefine citizens’ political and social role. Participatory budgeting has gradually built up a following around the world: in total, 1,500 municipalities, governments and institutions have tried this process since the 2000s. Cities in Ecuador, Peru, Argentina, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Sweden, the United Kingdom, France, Cameroon and China have tried this experiment.

Moreover, with the democratisation of the Internet, and in response to the economic crisis, new financing solutions are coming to light, such as crowdfunding. These web platforms allow citizens to invest in the projects they are passionate about, helping projects to benefit from quicker direct funding. The criteria of social and environmental utility are valued just as highly as purely financial criteria.

Institutional banks have also had to reinvent their practices, being faced with the ever higher expectations of citizens for greater transparency and social and environmental responsibility. SRI funds are certainly just a first step in this direction.

Is democratic water management possible? If so, what are its pros and cons? In Porto Alegre, Brazil, the implementation of participatory budgeting in the late 80s paved the way for democratic water management. Today, the city prides itself on registering the highest human development indicators in Brazil, thanks to the quality and coverage percentage of its water and sanitation services. The operational and financial autonomy of the DMAE (Departamento municipal de Agua e Esgoto), the transparency of its political and budgetary management, the implementation of participatory governance, and the priority granted to the poorest inhabitants have all created a “virtuous circle”. By appointing users and, in particular, women to decision-making positions, projects can be implemented that more accurately meet local needs, notably including the setting of fairer rates. Facilities benefit from clear, solid institutional organisation, where the place of users, whose representatives are elected, is crucial, while engineering and commercial services fall in line with local needs.

Is this a utopian management system? In any case, it must be freed from armed conflicts and corruption among central administrations. Other success stories, notably in South America and more specifically in Bolivia, give reason to believe in this path.

It is an inspiration for the old democracies to follow suit and reinvent a more participatory management of water access.

70 years: this was the average life expectancy in 2012. Life expectancy at birth can vary by up to twice as much depending on your country: in 2012, it was 76 years for a European and 58 years for an African. Progress in the fields of nutrition, sanitation and education, medical discoveries, healthcare and, more generally speaking, economic development have all increased the average life expectancy of the world’s population, but they have not resolved the “global health divide”.

The reason for this lies with economic disparities. 1.3 billion individuals live in “absolute poverty” on less than one dollar a day per person; they do not have access to drinking water and suffer from malnutrition. The most vulnerable countries lack equipment, qualified healthcare professionals and pharmaceutical industries.

Furthermore, the lack of education, but also certain beliefs and customs, can play a significant role in holding back poor health conditions.

The World Bank recently reported that pandemics are one of the three major threats to our planet – along with climate change and commercial crises. Indeed, according to realistic estimates, a severe influenza pandemic could decrease global GDP by 4.8%, the equivalent of 3,600 billion dollars (based on 2013 global GDP).

International market finance could have serious repercussions on public health around the world. This was particularly the case when speculation on food commodities was the aggravating factor behind the 2007-2008 food crisis. According to the FAO, the 2007-2008 crisis significantly increased poverty and hunger around the world.

In the field of healthcare, the finger is currently pointing at the biotechnology sector. The meteoric rise of businesses in this sector is raising fears about a speculative bubble. The stock index of biotech companies has seen its price soar (over 35% in a year). Should we worry when we see that these few highly specialised companies with a few hundred employees are all worth more on the stock exchange than the infamous and influential Goldman Sachs bank? Indeed, new stakeholders are now investing in healthcare, such as the American Internet giant Google. Google is financing Calico, with the clear aim of focusing its efforts on combating ageing and age-related illnesses with its project “to solve death”. While such initiatives are the talk of the town, we should reduce the influence of giants like Google, who do not just become involved in global healthcare unless there are major acquisitions to be had.

Drinking tap water, washing, doing the laundry: these simple tasks may seem trivial to many of us.

However, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO), in 2013, 768 million people (11% of the world’s population) did not have access to drinking water and over a third of the planet (2.4 billion people) was not connected to a sanitation network, especially in rural areas. Waterborne infectious diseases cause up to 3.2 million deaths per year, which account for about 6% of deaths worldwide. These diseases include cholera, malaria, dengue fever, typhoid fever and even salmonella, to name but a few.

However, the way in which we try to stay healthy also has a major impact on water quality. In fact, with the development of medicines and pharmacy, water is being heavily polluted by the medicines released into the environment from urine, stools, wastage, emissions from the chemical and pharmaceutical industries and industrial livestock. These medicines are not completely broken down when they reach water treatment plants. Medicinal residues therefore enter into the food chain and, in turn, can have an impact on public health. Once again, we have come full circle.

The world’s population reached 4 billion in 1974, the date of the 1st oil crisis, 6 billion in 1999 and 7.3 billion in 2015. At the same time, the development of global finance and the financialisation of the economy have led to an exponential increase in inequalities. According to Oxfam, the 85 richest people on the planet have as much as the 3.5 billion poorest people. However, global wealth soared by 68% between 2003 and 2013. The accumulation of wealth by a few groups and several personal fortunes has led Thomas Piketty in his work “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” to show that since the financialisation of the economy began in the 80s, capital has accumulated more wealth than labour.

Low growth rates have once again become the norm in developed countries. Even though, at the same time, the profitability of capital has bounced back, it is now more about profit from capital income rather than profit from labour income that has set in and benefits the wealthiest members of society. In the long-term, this dynamic places a growing emphasis on legacy.

What will happen when there are the 10 billion people forecast for 2050? Can we imagine a financing system for the economy and human activities that is not geared towards the excessive increase in wealth of a few individuals but one that would contribute to a more equitable distribution of wealth? This is one of the major challenges of the first half of the 21st century.

10% of fresh water is used for our household consumption: quenching our thirst, washing, cleaning our homes, etc.; while 70% is used for agriculture. The world’s population is currently increasing by approximately 80 million people per year, which equates to a rise in demand for fresh water by about 64 billion cubic metres per year. Water withdrawals have therefore tripled over the last fifty years. This trend can largely be attributed to the rapid development of irrigation, which has been driven by food demand since the 1970s and by the continued growth of agriculture-based economies.

With 9.6 billion people expected by 2050, this demographic pressure is showing no signs of slowing down. There is bound to be a shortage of fresh water since it is a limited resource, widening inequalities between countries that already have sanitation infrastructures and the other poorer countries that are already poorly equipped. By 2030, it is estimated that 47% of the world’s population will be living in areas of “high water stress”.

Drinking water is a common good, a right we should all enjoy. Nowadays, the World Bank finances most water supplies, while private multinationals (Bechtel, Suez, Vivendi, Lyonnaise des eaux, RWE/Thames Water and Saur) manage approximately 5% of the world’s water resources.

According to the World Water Council, huge investment is required in developing countries to modernise their existing infrastructures and to create new equipment (production plants, distribution networks, sanitation plants, etc.), but also to develop new irrigation systems. The World Water Council estimates this investment at 180 billion dollars per year over the next 25 years, while only 75 billion dollars are currently being invested each year. Who should finance this investment? D

o we have to privatise water management? Who should set the price of water? The Water Council strongly recommends calling on private investors, while NGOs criticise this approach, where the State would play the role of a “mere regulator”. Their main argument is that this privatisation would always work to the detriment of the poorest populations on the planet and would not even guarantee greater efficiency.

Connaissez-vous le « grolar » ou « pizzly » ? Cet ours blanc aux tâches marrons découvert dans le Nord du Canada est le résultat d’un coup de foudre inattendu entre une femelle ours polaire et un mâle grizzly. Ils n’auraient pu ne jamais se rencontrer, mais c’était sans compter sur la fonte de la banquise. Ainsi, l’ours blanc est redescendu vers le sud du Canada et l’ours brun est remonté vers les toundras du Nord. Une illustration plutôt insolite de la relation complexe entre climat et biodiversité.

Depuis l’apparition de la vie sur terre et bien avant l’apparition de l’espèce humaine, le climat a toujours façonné la biodiversité, ses zones de vie et ses paysages. Les organismes vivants d’une région donnée se sont ainsi adaptés au fil du temps aux évolutions climatiques, aux fluctuations de la concentration des différents gaz qui composent l’atmosphère, des températures et du cycle de l’eau. Inversement, la régulation du climat repose en grande partie sur la qualité et la diversité des écosystèmes qui agissent sur les grands cycles comme l’eau ou le carbone. Les plantes, grâce à la photosynthèse, absorbent du dioxyde de carbone, produisent de l’oxygène et régulent notre climat.

When we talk about “sustainable development”, we often think of the preservation of endangered species and biodiversity. The protection of threatened species has been an important factor in understanding the very idea of sustainable development. It is also one of the most covered issues by the media, as we can see from the campaigns run by the World Wildlife Fund (WWF). Indeed, a society that wants to last is a society that knows how to preserve the sustainability of these natural elements, allowing future generations to enjoy their benefits. The preservation of biodiversity is therefore at the heart of sustainable development.

At the 2002 Johannesburg Summit, over one hundred heads of state, several tens of thousands of government officials and NGOs ratified a treaty on the conservation of natural resources and biodiversity. The IUCN was set up with the goal of listing all the endangered animal and plant species.

Does the idea of a universal island that belongs to all of us and yet to none of us seem crazy to you? As strange as it may seem, located very close to the North Pole, Hans Island still withstands all invaders. Given its vast oil resources, countries like Denmark and Canada have been trying to claim it as theirs. The Hans Universalis community wants the island to have the status of Terra nullius – a land that is not subject to the sovereignty of any state – which is recognised by the UN and the International Court of Justice.

Biodiversity is a common good to share; nature does not belong to anyone. Certain countries and industries are carelessly exploiting land that had been well-preserved up until now. An increasing number of big industry projects are at loggerheads with environmental groups because they are destroying this common good that is biodiversity. In France, recent claims in ZAD (zones to defend) – Notre Dame des Landes against the airport project and Sivens against the dam project – show that citizens want their voices to be heard on the exploitation of their environment. In Guatemala, the Xalala dam project is threatening the indigenous population who will lose their land. Should we establish greater democracy when a project affects a common good ? And how can we come to a democratic decision? Can we speak out on behalf of nature and who should protect biodiversity?

Biodiversity plays a crucial role for human health.

It is estimated that almost half of the medicines we use come from natural active products extracted from living organisms. Thyme provides the thymol used as an antifungal treatment, mint provides the menthol used as a vasodilator, colchicum supplies the colchicine used as an anti-tumour agent, the yew tree produces the taxol used to treat certain cancers, while willow bark is used to make aspirin. These medicines are therefore one of the many ecosystem services which nature provides. Furthermore, ecosystems play a role in regulating our climate, filtering and cleaning dirty water, and keeping land fit for farming.

The loss of biodiversity could therefore have serious direct consequences on human health, if ecosystem services no longer meet the needs of our society. As a source of knowledge and discoveries, the loss of biodiversity would deprive us of new potential treatments against current and future diseases.

By adopting a systemic approach, it will lead us to question our health’s dependence on biodiversity, but also, conversely, the effects of our healthcare practices on biodiversity. The antibiotics that we take – or that we feed to our livestock to provide us with food – are therefore released into the environment, polluting water and soil. So it is quite a precarious balance.

Have you ever heard of the bee-men? Following the decline of natural ecosystems in the Sichuan Province of China, people have had to do nature’s job, replacing bees and pollinating the orchard flowers one by one by hand.

The growth of the world’s population will continue to rise dramatically throughout the 21st century. Having grown from 2 billion people to 7 billion over the course of the 20th century, our population should stabilise between 9 and 10 billion towards 2050. This demographic pressure has a major impact on our environment and contributes heavily to the loss of biodiversity. It increases our needs for:
- infrastructures for accommodation, transportation and communication;
- agricultural and food production;
- energy production for lighting, heating, transportation and communication.

Faced with these growing production and performance targets, up until now we have prioritised industrial, energy and agricultural solutions that have had devastating effects on biodiversity, leading to what scientists call the sixth mass extinction of species. There is a clear risk that if we lose the ecosystems that gave birth to human life on Earth, our survival will be at stake.

It is certainly not a matter of competition or choice between human life on the one side and the preservation of ecosystems on the other. On the contrary, the challenge is to recognise that our quality of life and the fulfilment which we will enjoy tomorrow depends directly on how our development decisions take into account the interdependency between mankind and the other animal and plant species in our ecosystem.

How much is the beauty of a countryside rich in animal and plant diversity worth against the financial power of multinationals? Must we place a value on life before people will recognise the richness it represents and the services it provides us?

According to certain scientists, the monetisation of life would just sell off the destruction of nature on a global scale. This is happening right now with carbon credits, which allow certain countries to pay for a “right to pollute”. Furthermore, it lifts the technical barriers linked to monetary assessment methods, as well as any ethical or legal issues. Last but not least, excessive speculation, as in the case of carbon finance, would represent a major risk to anticipate.

While conversely, other experts think that we should place a value on life since it would “create a dialogue and make a strong argument in support of incorporating biodiversity into economic and political decisions”. Placing a value on life would therefore make stakeholders accountable for any negative externalities caused by the risks of biodiversity loss.

Water is essential for life. Animals, plants and humans all need water to ensure their survival and development. Ever since water first appeared on Earth about 4 billion years ago, its volume has remained the same. The same water is constantly circulated, converted and recycled, which is known as the water cycle. Human beings and animals are made of water; it helps to regulate their body temperature and remove their waste.

In turn, biodiversity plays a key role in maintaining the quality and quantity of water available. The water cycle is influenced by ecosystems and their life. They regulate the movement of water in the earth, filter the water so it is drinkable and help distribute the nutrients in the soil. Forests and mangroves therefore help this cycle to run properly. As a whole, these processes help combat erosion and prevent the risk of droughts and floods, all while regulating the quality and availability of water. These ecosystem services therefore form a sort of “natural infrastructure” for water.

Consequently, water pollution by many human activities is all the more devastating. Water reserves and wetlands are some of the most threatened biodiversity on the planet.

Have you ever heard of a “grolar” or a “pizzly”? These white bears with brown patches discovered in northern Canada were bred from a chance encounter between a female polar bear and a male grizzly. They might have never met if it was not for the melting ice caps. However, the white bear journeyed back to southern Canada and the brown bear travelled back to the northern tundras. This shows one, albeit rather unusual, example of the complex relationship between climate and biodiversity.

Ever since the dawn of life on Earth, and long before human life began, the climate has always shaped biodiversity, its habitats and its landscapes. The living organisms in any given region have therefore adapted over time to climate change and to fluctuations in the make-up of the various atmospheric gases, temperatures and water cycle.

Conversely, climate regulation largely relies on the quality and diversity of the ecosystems that affect the major cycles, such as the water and carbon cycles. Through photosynthesis, plants absorb carbon dioxide, produce oxygen and regulate our climate.

Torrey Canyon, March 1967. The Amoco Cadiz, March 1978. Ixtoc 1, June 1979. Atlantic Express, July 1979. Odyssey, 1988. Exxon Valdez, March 1989. The Haven, April 1991. Deepwater Horizon, April 2010.

No, this is not a list of action films, but rather the terrible oil spills that have been etched on our minds and on our planet throughout the past century. The main victims are birds, marine mammals, corals and fish, but whole ecosystems are affected. We could also include the ongoing deliberate pollution in the Gulf of Guinea - the equivalent every year of all the oil spilled in the Gulf of Mexico during the Deepwater catastrophe - or even the oil sands of Canada. In Alberta, open-pit mining of oil sand deposits - which represent the third largest crude oil reserve in the world - is spoiling vast areas of land and is contaminating the soil and the surrounding waters. Toxic lakes, rivers transformed into industrial sewers, forests cut down and all while bitumen is supposedly the “cleanest” oil in the world.

On a more global scale, the exploitation of fossil fuels and the overdependence of lifestyles in industrialised countries on these fuels represent the leading cause of climate change and, consequently, of the destruction of ecosystems and biodiversity. This is all the more dramatic given that some of these natural systems are vital for absorbing our carbon emissions and consequently for limiting global warming.

Biodiversity is our life insurance.

Just like all living species, human beings live interdependently with the other animal and plant species in their ecosystem. The mass extinction of species that we are seeing and the degradation of natural environments make human beings vulnerable. The large ecoregions that make up our planet do not end at countries’ borders. We need to adopt regional, even global, policies to preserve human living conditions on Earth.

The IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) was founded in 1948 “to influence, encourage and assist societies throughout the world to conserve the integrity and diversity of nature and to ensure that any use of natural resources is equitable and ecologically sustainable” Since the 1992 Rio Summit, the preservation of biodiversity has become a major challenge for the more sustainable development of our societies. The Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) was adopted and signed by 176 countries during this summit. Much like the IPCC, the Intergovernmental Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) was set up to advise governments on this issue. While attempts at international cooperation have been made, much still remains to be done, in particular, the implementation of adapted levels of governance.

The loss of biodiversity is making our food security vulnerable.

Just four plant species - wheat, corn, rice and potatoes - account for 50% of the plant calories in the world today, while 18 species account for 80%. In Ireland in the 19th century, the national diet mainly consisted of a single variety of potato; when it was hit by an epidemic, it caused a major famine that wiped out between 1 and 1.5 million people. The globalisation and standardisation of the food model throughout the 20th century has led to the loss of 75% of the diversity of crops produced up until that point (FAO, 2010).

By privatising and patenting living organisms such as seeds, by trying to maximise short-term agricultural performance to the detriment of maintaining a less predictable diversity, and by preventing farmers from storing a part of their harvest to replant the following year, it has limited the resilience of the global agricultural production system (its ability to adapt to future developments that we cannot foresee). The global organisation of the food chain has therefore become highly dependent on a few global industrial groups and on the seeds they select for everyone.

It is inconceivable that our telephones could be used as weapons of mass destruction.

Rare earths are strategic materials that are essential for our smartphones, computer screens, means of transport and solar panels. However, they are obtained from mining and purification techniques that cause extreme levels of pollution in the soil, water and air. By releasing toxic substances, acids and radioactive elements, these techniques pollute and destroy whole ecosystems, causing harmful health effects and contributing to the loss of biodiversity.

In the near future, exploration is planned of the deep sea beds and of the land freed up by melting ice in order to meet the growing global demand in our limited resources of metals and rare earths. However, this will threaten new ecosystems that had been relatively well-preserved up until now. On the other hand, biodiversity holds much hope! It can give a second life to these rare metals. It has been discovered that the common soil bacteria, Desulfovibrio desulfuricans, can recover palladium, one of the rare metals used in our telephones, computers and fax machines. These very small particles preserve palladium’s catalytic power, according to researchers at Birmingham University. They are “an excellent catalyst for the treatment of persistent pollutants, such as chromium, which is used in the paint industry”, explained Dr Deplanche. The group also believes that these palladium nanoparticles could be used to generate “clean electricity from hydrogen” in a fuel cell.

The first forecasts of global warming were made back in 1967. Two scientists predicted that CO2 levels would double by the beginning of the 21st century and average temperatures would rise by 2.5 degrees. Nearly 20 years later, in 1988, the IPCC was founded. The climate is the focal point of today’s environmental concerns and plays a key role in spreading the idea of sustainable development.

However, is this concept of sustainable “development” compatible with our fight against global warming? Growing energy demand is closely linked to GDP growth and therefore to development. Development causes a rise in energy consumption, which is responsible for climate change. Consequently, wouldn’t the concept of degrowth be more appropriate than “sustainable development”, when we consider that one of the greatest challenges of the future is the issue of the climate and therefore lowering demand for non-renewable energies?

How can we adapt our democratic models to major environmental challenges that know no boundaries? Is global democracy realistic?

The climate challenge knows no boundaries. Even though 10 countries in the world are responsible for 70% of greenhouse gas emissions, the effects of global warming are uneven. Global governance is required, while swift and effective decisions must be taken. To this end, is the fight against climate change compatible with democracy? Is global awareness on this issue possible? Even in our globalised world rich in cultures and customs, can we all adopt a more environmentally friendly lifestyle? What is the place of individual freedom? Do we need an “enlightened” dictatorship to resolve the climate issue?

More frequent and intense heatwaves, changes to living environments, as well as animal and human migrations are some of the expected effects of global warming. These changes are going to have a substantial impact on human health. New diseases are going to emerge and we will be left unprepared. For example, tropical diseases are going to develop in areas where the climate is currently mild. Between 2030 and 2050, climate change is expected to cause almost 250,000 extra deaths per year due to malnutrition, malaria, diarrhoea and heat stress. The cost of the direct damage to health is estimated at between 2 and 4 billion US dollars per year until 2030.

Furthermore, any areas without good health infrastructures, mostly in developing countries, will be the least prepared to face this situation without assistance. While broadening our choice of transport, food and energy, the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions could also lead to an improvement in health.

Population growth will automatically accentuate climate change. The western lifestyle produces an extremely high amount of GHG and seems to serve as the economic development model for the rest of the world.

Nevertheless, different countries’ contribution to global warming is not directly proportional to their population. For example, China has the highest population in the world and is also the leading producer of GHG. However, its CO2 emissions per capita are far behind those of the United States, Canada, Australia, Russia and European countries.

Furthermore, climate change is going to have a strong impact on agricultural conditions (less new land for farming, more severe natural disasters, greater uncertainty over harvests, etc.) and increase food insecurity for a large majority of the 10 billion people who will inhabit the Earth by 2050.

Global warming will also cause major population displacements. By 2050, between 150 and 200 million people are expected to migrate due to climate change, whether it is caused by rising sea levels or by worsening droughts, famine, etc. (source: Christian Aid).

Finance helps development...and this development generates carbon emissions. However, global finance has a key role to play in combating global warming through what is known as carbon finance.

The objective is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the atmosphere by encouraging financial investment in cleaner technologies. Finance is therefore one of the tools at our disposal to steer investments towards more emission-friendly initiatives and can help strengthen our resilience to the effects of climate change. To this end, carbon taxes are one of the tools provided to guide the economy and human behaviour towards cleaner solutions.

Water and the climate are inextricably linked. Global warming will cause more frequent and more pronounced floods and droughts, which will affect river systems and water resources. Furthermore, rising sea levels are going to pose a threat to coastlines, but also risk causing the intrusion of salt water into fresh water aquifers. Approximately 1% of seawater would be enough to alter groundwater quality. Over 2 billion people in the world depend on groundwater for their access to drinking water.

Global warming is also melting certain glaciers. However, many people depend on these glaciers for their water access. Controlling climate change is therefore a key challenge. All the more so since it will tie in with the world’s rising population and with the concentration of people in major cities which consume large amounts of water. In 2050, about 75% of the world’s population will live in cities.

“Climate change is one of the greatest challenges of our time”, according to Kofi Annan, the 7th Secretary-General of the United Nations.

We all share the same planet and the climate challenge knows no boundaries! However, some countries pollute more than others (10 countries in the world are responsible for 70% of greenhouse gas emissions), while other regions, including some of the poorest on the planet, will be the ones most affected by global warming.

Implementing global coordination is a major challenge. The climate issue will not be resolved at local level. It has to transcend individual political and economic interests to guide global common interest towards maintaining living conditions that support human life on Earth. Since all the regions in the world are affected, it is a daunting intercultural challenge.

In 1988, the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) was set up to shed an international, unbiased scientific light on this issue. At the 1992 Rio Earth Summit, 192 countries signed the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), thereby committing to stabilise their greenhouse gas emissions. The decision was made to hold an annual conference, known as the “Conference of the Parties” (COP), to decide on how the Convention could be practically implemented. This is how the basis for Global Climate Governance was formed. The critical nature of climate issues will force us to strengthen and step up these talks.

Lithium, radium, cobalt, copper and iron: there is a whole host of metals hidden in all our everyday private life objects. They are so close to us that we do not even realise they are there. We no longer know how they are made and we forget that they do not last forever. It consumes an incredible amount of energy to mine these resources from the earth in very limited quantities, and to convert them for our homes, infrastructures, transport, computers, telephones, paints, etc. At the moment, this energy is essentially generated from fossil fuels, which are the leading cause behind GHG emissions and therefore climate change.

While the mining of these metals and rare earths contributes to global warming, the effects of this warming can also lead to valuable discoveries which will be of the greatest interest to certain countries. This is the case in Greenland, where the melting ice cap is revealing its treasures and making them more accessible. After China, this region has the 2nd biggest reserve of rare earths in the world and the fifth largest uranium reserve! According to initial explorations, Greenland could meet 25% of global demand for rare earths.

The issue of energy and the increasing shortage of fossil fuels is behind the idea of sustainable development. In 1972, the Meadows report (the limits to growth), published by the Club of Rome, highlighted the challenge which energy represents for the future of mankind.

More generally speaking, energy is the driving force behind the development models of our societies. Beyond the sheer quantity of energy we consume, a society’s energy model “creates its system”: this includes the type of resources used (and their potential repercussions on the environment and on populations), the infrastructures (power plants and distribution grids), as well as the equipment to meet our energy service needs (individual cars or public transport, household electrical appliances, etc.). Since these energy services are at the heart of all human activities, from the most essential requirements (accommodation, heating, food, etc.) to the most trivial ones for certain hobbies, how they are addressed is intrinsically linked to the level of development and organisation of society.

We have different choices to make: a centralised or devolved system across the regions? Obscure technical expertise or citizen participation? The exploitation of rare resources in limited quantities or the use of renewable energies? Our answers to these questions will reflect the very structure of our societies but will also influence our societies, determining how we will live together for decades to come.

Access to energy and to the energy services that it provides is on the way to becoming a basic right . But major inequalities still exist. Is the challenge for tomorrow to build a “global energy democracy”? Do we agree with Timothy Mitchell that energy sources “bring political models”?

Overly centralised energy models based on rare resources (oil, gas and uranium) do not help populations to recognise their energy needs, how they address these needs, the actual cost of their energy system, or the potential alternatives available to them.

Some people think that western countries’ eagerness for the rest of the world to adopt the democratic model hides their vague attempt to gain control over strategic energy resources. For their part, countries rich in natural deposits seem to be condemned to suffer a “resource curse” and do not have access to basic democracy.

On the other hand, the transition towards a model based on renewable energies (solar, wind, biomass, etc.) would lead to a form of democratic reappropriation by redistributing the sources of production. It would even allow the direct involvement of citizens’ organisations, in particular cooperative associations and participatory financing.

The consumption of fossil fuels causes major pollution that affects people’s health. The biggest consumers of coal in the world, like China, are now paying the heavy price in terms of their public health. On a global scale, a ir pollution caused by road transport kills as many people as traffic accidents (WHO, 2002).

The air inside many homes around the world is still more lethal than the outdoor air pollution, due to their crude, unsafe cooking and heating methods (firewood, old coal-fired boilers, etc.). The issue of health is at the centre of discussions on nuclear energy: nuclear accidents such as Chernobyl and Fukushima have devastated entire regions, irradiating populations and food chains far beyond the geographical area directly affected.

Conversely, energy access improves living conditions, education and health. To a certain extent, we can therefore see a strong correlation between energy consumption and life expectancy. In industrialised countries, when faced with fuel poverty or an energy divide, the thermal renovation of homes should be a priority public policy. In addition to making life more comfortable and lowering energy consumption, it reduces health risks and improves the air quality inside homes.

The growth of the world’s population (9 to 10 billion in 2050) and its incremental increase in wealth are expected to result in a considerable rise in global energy consumption. This is all the more true since the lifestyle in industrialised countries seems to serve as the development model for the rest of the world, even though it consumes an extremely large amount of fossil fuels. Conversely, energy access is a major factor in the development and empowerment of population groups. Indeed, energy access facilitates access to school education, reduces gender inequalities, significantly improves public health and thereby helps to reduce poverty. By creating a more secure environment for families, energy access coincides more or less rapidly with a decline in birth rates and therefore with an easing of demographic pressure.

However, there still remains the major challenge of bridging the gap between the current huge inequalities in energy access, whether on a global scale or within the same country.

Financial leverage has been, and still remains, an extremely powerful tool to support the development of carbon economies. Direct and indirect subsidies for the development of fossil fuels and also for the nuclear industry have led to this illusion of more expensive and almost infinite energy, holding people back from realising its true cost. The cost is its limitation over time, since the reserves in our subsoil are limited, but there is also the cost of the negative externalities which are not included in the display price, even though the community will end up paying heavily one way or another (pollution, public health, wars over reserves, etc.).

In terms of the investment and aid for North/South development, banks’ policies have only very recently, and still very marginally, begun to question the value of continuing to support fossil fuels or whether they should, on the contrary, promote the development of renewable energies.

We are collectively beginning to realise that the cost of doing nothing about climate change and our energy models will be a much higher price to pay in the end than the short-term answer of investing in energy transition.

Water has always been a mechanical source of energy. One of the first forms of energy was the use of rivers’ currents to turn millers’ grindstones, pistons and turbines. The advantage of this type of energy production is that it does not consume large amounts of energy, but on the downside it generates a low output. Much of the infrastructure used to produce energy from water requires the construction of dams, which cause other human and social problems and contribute to the loss of biodiversity. Furthermore, the exploitation of fossil fuels significantly pollutes and contaminates the water reserves used for agriculture and food. The situation is even more dramatic for the exploitation of unconventional resources (shale gas and oil sands).

On the other hand, through the desalination of seawater, energy power provides a possible answer for any regions chronically short of fresh water. But yet again, this is a very energy-intensive process, so the challenge once again lies with the type of energy that will provide this fresh water supply.

Energy and in particular fossil fuels (oil, coal and gas) are at the heart of our development models and have enabled major technological revolutions. They account for 81% of the energy consumed in the world and contribute 60% of greenhouse gas emissions, which are responsible for climate change. If we are to enjoy the upcoming global economic development, in particular in the countries of the South, following this model is not compatible with our fight against global warming. Furthermore, our current energy infrastructures are very susceptible to extreme weather conditions, i.e. thermal power plants that are very susceptible to heat, or renewable energies (solar and wind) whose output may be affected by the rise in unpredictable weather.

Models are emerging that advocate a swift yet reasoned transition to renewable energies, including the relocation of power generation facilities.

The climate challenge places energy at the epicentre of the major global economic, political and diplomatic issues.

The dwindling gas and oil reserves, faced with the growing energy demand from emerging economies, have strengthened the political and strategic dimension of energy supplies. Moreover, countries’ eagerness to secure their energy supplies is causing numerous conflicts (Ukraine-Russia, China-Vietnam, Arctic-Antarctic, Gulf countries, etc.). On other fronts, the uranium supply for nuclear energy generation is causing tension, armed conflicts and corruption.

International regulation is required if we want to quell these geopolitical conflicts and address global warming, but it would need countries to reaffirm their political will so it would be heard by the global private stakeholders who govern the world’s energy trade.

Conversely, the wide use of renewable energies would redistribute the sources of production across different regions, thereby reducing the challenge of appropriating limited and unevenly distributed resources on the planet. Consequently, this would defuse many international conflicts. This would finally leave international bodies to deal with other issues, such as education, women’s conditions, happiness, etc.

Metals need energy and energy needs metals.

While between 8 and 10% of the world’s primary energy is used to mine or refine metals, 5% of the world’s steel is currently used to extract oil and gas. Highly energy-intensive processes are needed to mine these precious metals that are found in many of our everyday objects. As the concentration of metals in the earth diminishes, an increasing amount of energy is required to extract them. A little bit like a love story which could end badly, some people are talking about a “peak all”, a threshold when we will simultaneously reach the limits of our resources of oil, gas and the main metals.

While renewable energies (wind farms and solar panels) are also dependent on metals, they require much smaller amounts. Unless we find new technologies that do not depend on rare, energy-intensive resources, only a radical change in our production methods and consumption patterns could collectively lead us into a virtuous circle.

Environmental and societal issues (for example, climate change, biodiversity loss, food security and water management) are leading to the redevelopment of collective coordination methods. It is a matter of managing “common goods” with a long-term approach, rising above the economic interests of different countries and private stakeholders.

International standards and agreements are being drafted within various frameworks: international treaties, multilateral agreements, Conferences of the Parties, etc., during international environmental negotiations and various forums. The involvement of stakeholders on a global level, such as the COP21 for the climate, brings in non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and private individuals, without whom it would not be possible to implement anything effective or sustainable.

Does a world population exist? Are we all “citizens of the world”? At a time when the Internet is revolutionising our relationship with power, institutions and citizenship, do we have to plan for a “global democracy”?

While over half of the world’s population live under the yoke of authoritarian regimes, the democratic model is often considered as the best form of public organisation for society and the most respectful of individual rights. Nevertheless, it is being increasingly challenged, in particular with regard to the lack of example set by the major democracies.

Furthermore, is it wise to hope to secure international agreements with undemocratic regimes for the general interest of the population, when some people think that these regimes have little concern for their own people?

While some people dispute the very idea of a global democracy, many authorities (countries, scientists, civil society representatives, etc.) are making their voices heard within international institutional organisations, calling for general interests to be prioritised over national interests.

“In the 21st century, health is a shared responsibility, involving equitable access to essential care and collective defence against transnational threats” (WHO, 2014).

The recent epidemic of the extremely viral and often fatal Ebola virus in West Africa clearly emphasised the need for international cooperation in healthcare. In addition to the Ebola crisis, there has been the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), the polio outbreak in the Middle East and Africa, as well as the plague in Madagascar. These are only the latest examples of the difficulty governments face in controlling the spread of infectious diseases when they work alone: the global rules negotiated among governmental authorities are vital for protecting citizens’ health (Source: Finance & Development, December 2014).

Access to drinking water and a sufficiently rich diet are the first building block of access to health. Similarly to the right to food, health is a human right. However, private pharmaceutical industries are turning health into a real market economy. The boundary line between private and public interests is blurred, making the regulation system highly complex and questioning the feasibility of an equitable, fair and effective healthcare system.

There will be between 9 and 10 billion people by 2050. There will be just as many mouths to feed, families to house, children to look after, energy to provide, etc. Some people think that we will have to curb global population growth in light of future environmental, social and economic global challenges. But is that even possible? History shows us that demographic policies have little effect.

While experience tells us that demographic transition, which leads to a stabilised population following a fall in birth and death rates, is directly linked to a population’s economic and social development and more specifically to the educational level of women.

The world’s population is not just growing but is moving around the world as well: climate refugees, flows of epidemics, brain drain, tax avoidance, etc. Do we have to control migratory flows? How can we implement fair global governance which takes into account countries’ specific interests without undermining individual freedoms? Global governance of the population poses more questions than answers and for each issue it leads us to make a decision on the world we want to live in, celebrating all our diversity.

Countries’ interdependence, in particular from an economic and commercial perspective, is a major factor in global stability or instability: if a country’s economy slows down, it can affect the economies of its neighbouring countries. The 2007 financial crisis, which began in the United States and then snowballed around the whole world, highlighted the need for global financial regulation.

Even though there are certain institutions, organisations and summits, such as the IMF (International Monetary Fund), the FSC (Financial Stability Committee), the G20 summit and the Basel Committee, the markets generally remain beyond the control of the State. Founded after the Second World War, these institutions specifically aimed to improve the stability of the global economy and therefore to bring forward its recognition as a global public good.

Are the existing international standards sufficient when faced with the power and automation of the financial markets? Can we still believe in a fully transparent financial system regulated by the State, when some countries seem to take orders from this financial system?

While two thirds of the world’s population could find themselves suffering from “water stress” by 2025, international management of drinking water is becoming essential in certain regions around the world to guarantee its protection and access. Water is essential for life and a human right, a global public good. However, 11% of the world’s population does not currently have access to water. This plague no longer only blights the least developed countries. Recently, the inhabitants of Detroit in the United States had to appeal to the UN after too many people had their water cut off.

Agriculture uses 70% of drinking water for watering. Effective and intelligent allocation of water is therefore essential, as new forms of irrigation come to light. This task is made all the more difficult by the tensions between advocates of global public management and private stakeholders looking to make a profit on their investments. International institutions have been set up, such as the World Water Council, to encourage discussion and provide a global perspective on water issues.

“Blue gold” is a dwindling resource, which creates tensions in areas such as the Golan Heights in the Middle East, the Mekong in Asia and even along the Nile in Africa.

Si les Anglais se réjouissent de bientôt pouvoir produire du bon vin grâce à un climat plus clément, l’insécurité alimentaire pourrait empirer sous l’effet des dérèglements climatiques : cyclones plus violents, canicules plus fréquentes, disparition des deltas fertiles ou avancée des déserts sur les savanes, les effets sur l’agriculture seront dramatiques. Cela pourrait entrainer pertes de récoltes, baisses de rendements, hausse des prix des denrées alimentaires, baisse des revenus des agriculteurs et migrations massives depuis les régions affectées vers les régions voisines.

En 2010, les sécheresses en Russie et en Australie, couplée avec les inondations au Pakistan ont produit un triplement du prix du blé. En 2012, le Midwest américain a connu la pire sécheresse en 50 ans, ce qui a réduit la récolte de maïs attendue de 25% et participé à l’augmentation à des prix du maïs dans le monde, en hausse de près de 40%. L’Afrique, continent le plus concerné par l’insécurité alimentaire, sera durement touché : on estime qu’au-delà d’un réchauffement global de 2 degrés, la production agricole de l’Afrique subsaharienne pourrait décroître de 20% à 30% d’ici à 2080.

Mais le problème est fort complexe : si l’agriculture, surtout tropicale, va fortement souffrir avec le réchauffement climatique, elle en est aussi une des causes principales : on estime qu’actuellement elle émet de 20 à 25 % des gaz à effet de serre. Avec le développement prévu de l’élevage dans le monde, elle devrait émettre le tiers des gaz à effet de serre à échéance 2030 !

The issue of food security is at the heart of the challenges of building sustainable societies. Furthermore, the crossover between food issues and environmental issues and health hazards has largely contributed to the spread of the very challenges of sustainable development.

In terms of the environment, agriculture, which covers a large part of the planet’s surface, is directly affected by global warming and the increasing shortage of natural resources. The same applies for the seas and their fish resources. For land, water, biodiversity and the energy model, there has never been such a pressing urgency to find new management models so that the methods used for food today do not prevent future generations from feeding themselves properly.

We must now find ecologically intensive agricultural techniques, which produce better quality and quantity but use less non-renewable resources. From an economic perspective, when facing the challenge of feeding 9 to 10 billion people in 2050, it is essential that farmers can earn a living from their job and even invest to improve production. Due to the world’s growing population, we will need all the farmers in the world and we must therefore ensure that the most powerful do not suffocate the most vulnerable agricultural models.

From a social point of view, everyone’s right to eat and to eat well must remain a leading objective for the international community. As proven during previous centuries, hunger creates insecurity, forced emigration, epidemics, wars, piracy, terrorism, etc. Humanity pays a heavy price!

Dictatorships and totalitarian regimes develop very different strategies for the food security of their people:
- Some really invest in this issue and try to develop agriculture to meet local needs. For example, it cannot be denied that the Chinese regime has had some great victories in this area and has proven to be much more effective than the democratic systems of India or Vietnam.
- While others like North Korea seem to have little concern for the food security of their people, sometimes even creating chronic malnourishment and famine.
